articles.headline: The Rise and Fall of a Rainmaker
articles.snippet: John Altorelli, a high-flying partner at Dewey & LeBoeuf, the law firm that collapsed in 2012, filed for personal bankruptcy last month and is being targeted on several fronts.
articles.abstract: John Altorelli, a high-flying partner at Dewey & LeBoeuf, the law firm that collapsed in 2012, filed for personal bankruptcy last month and is being targeted on several fronts.
articles.lead_paragraph: The messy collapse of the mega-firm Dewey & LeBoeuf has claimed another casualty, and this time it’s one of the defunct law firm’s leading rainmakers.

articles.headline: Sensing a Deal on Sanctions, Iran Is Bullish
articles.snippet: Confidence is building in Iran’s business circles, with executives in the major export industries preparing for what they see as prosperous days ahead.
articles.abstract: Confidence is building in Iran’s business circles, with executives in the major export industries preparing for what they see as prosperous days ahead.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — The text message, received as the deadline for nuclear talks was expiring, gave Fatemeh Moghimi a thrill she had been waiting years to feel. “The deal,” it read, “was done.”

articles.headline: Life Insurers Use State Laws to Avoid as Much as $100 Billion in U.S. Taxes
articles.snippet: Insurance companies are taking advantage of fierce competition for their business among states to avoid federal taxes.
articles.abstract: Insurance companies are taking advantage of fierce competition for their business among states to avoid federal taxes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Some companies have been called economic traitors for seeking to lower their tax bills by moving overseas. But life insurers are accomplishing the same goal without leaving the country, saving as much as $100 billion in federal taxes, much of it in the last several years.

articles.headline: In New Election, Jeb Bush Stakes Out the Middle Ground
articles.snippet: Though Mr. Bush is deeply conservative on some issues, in other ways — culturally and philosophically — he is out of step with the grass-roots activists who animate the party nowadays.
articles.abstract: Though Mr. Bush is deeply conservative on some issues, in other ways — culturally and philosophically — he is out of step with the grass-roots activists who animate the party nowadays.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida quietly visited Senator John McCain in his Capitol Hill office this fall, discussion turned to a subject of increasing interest to Mr. Bush: how to run for president without pandering to the party’s conservative base.

articles.headline: Why U.S. Women Are Leaving Jobs Behind
articles.snippet: The work force participation of American women has declined, as it has for men. But their situation is often quite different.
articles.abstract: The work force participation of American women has declined, as it has for men. But their situation is often quite different.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since Kerry Devine, 32, and her friends began having children, she has noticed a stark difference between her female friends in Auburn, Wash., where she lives, and those in England and Cyprus, where she grew up. In the United States, they almost all stopped working outside the home, at least until their children were in school. Yet, she says, she can’t think of a friend in Europe who left work after her children were born.
articles.byline: By Claire Cain Miller and Liz Alderman

articles.headline: Revisiting Mortgages With Low Down Payments
articles.snippet: Two couples who bought homes in 2008 and 2010 and put 5 percent or less down are doing fine, but they have been tested.
articles.abstract: Two couples who bought homes in 2008 and 2010 and put 5 percent or less down are doing fine, but they have been tested.
articles.lead_paragraph: This week, the government released details of a plan to encourage more people to buy homes. Soon, it will be easier for banks to offer mortgages with down payments as low as 3 percent.

articles.headline: Oil Prices Fall Again, and Stocks Follow Suit
articles.snippet: The swoon in oil prices led to a steep decline in equities, as investors feared that the declining energy demand meant that the global economy was slowing.
articles.abstract: The swoon in oil prices led to a steep decline in equities, as investors feared that the declining energy demand meant that the global economy was slowing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Oil prices continued their collapse on Friday as evidence mounted that the frenzy of American oil production would continue well into 2015 even while growth in global demand was declining.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and Stanley Reed

articles.headline: At Big Banks, a Lesson Not Learned
articles.snippet: A scene that looks familiar on Wall Street: tripping over themselves, and the rules, to get business.
articles.abstract: A scene that looks familiar on Wall Street: tripping over themselves, and the rules, to get business.
articles.lead_paragraph: Are the colossal regulatory fines extracted from big banks today likely to deter their officials from violating the same rules tomorrow? Or are these billion-dollar settlements viewed simply as a cost of doing business, and not a very large one at that?

articles.headline: Good Intentions of Detroit Residents Are Tested by Blight
articles.snippet: Many Detroiters are willing to wait for promised change, but it has been slow to come. “The city has good intentions,” one resident said, “but then the actions are like a snail.”
articles.abstract: Many Detroiters are willing to wait for promised change, but it has been slow to come. “The city has good intentions,” one resident said, “but then the actions are like a snail.”
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — In and around the abandoned houses on Mount Vernon Street, brawls and shootings have erupted, a dogfighting ring has been established, stolen cars were traded and drug deals consummated. So when Michelle Van-Tardy, who has lived on the block for years, saw a disheveled woman in her 50s slip into the abandoned house at 569 Mount Vernon Street, she pounced.

articles.headline: Amid Details on Torture, Data on 26 Who Were Held in Error
articles.snippet: Of 119 prisoners in C.I.A custody, the Senate report found that 26 were either described in the agency’s own documents as mistakenly detained, or released and given money.
articles.abstract: Of 119 prisoners in C.I.A custody, the Senate report found that 26 were either described in the agency’s own documents as mistakenly detained, or released and given money.
articles.lead_paragraph: One quiet consequence of this week’s sensational release of the Senate Intelligence Committee’s report on the C.I.A. detention program was a telephone call that a human rights lawyer, Meg Satterthwaite, placed to a client in Yemen, Mohamed Bashmilah.

articles.headline: Ex-Chief Leads Vocal Defense of C.I.A.
articles.snippet: The counteroffensive, which includes a new website, began even before the Senate committee issued its report on the agency’s harsh treatment of detainees.
articles.abstract: The counteroffensive, which includes a new website, began even before the Senate committee issued its report on the agency’s harsh treatment of detainees.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The last time George Tenet was asked about torture on television, he sounded defiant and jabbed his finger in the air. The year was 2007, and Mr. Tenet, the former director of the Central Intelligence Agency, was promoting his memoir when a question about waterboarding came up while he was being interviewed on CBS’ “60 Minutes.”
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Eric Lichtblau

articles.headline: Small Bank in Kansas Is a Financial Testing Ground
articles.snippet: The owners of CBW in Weir, Kan., want to find solutions to problems — like obstacles to quick money transfers — that vex consumers nationwide.
articles.abstract: The owners of CBW in Weir, Kan., want to find solutions to problems — like obstacles to quick money transfers — that vex consumers nationwide.
articles.lead_paragraph: The redbrick bank in Weir, Kan., in a building cater-corner from the mortuary on Main Street, does not look much like a candidate for the bank of the future.

articles.headline: For Jihadists, Denmark Tries Rehabilitation
articles.snippet: A pioneering program treats former fighters not as criminals or potential terrorists, but as wayward youths who deserve a second chance.
articles.abstract: A pioneering program treats former fighters not as criminals or potential terrorists, but as wayward youths who deserve a second chance.
articles.lead_paragraph: AARHUS, Denmark — In many parts of Europe, he would now be in jail. But here in Denmark’s second biggest city, the young man, a 21-year-old of Turkish descent who spent 13 months in Syria fighting in the name of Islam, passes his days playing soccer, working out at the gym and waiting anxiously to see if he has secured a place to study engineering at a well-regarded local university.

articles.headline: China’s E-Cigarette Boom Lacks Oversight for Safety
articles.snippet: Almost all of the world’s e-cigarettes are made without oversight, and experts say flawed or sloppy manufacturing could account for some of the hazards seen in the devices.
articles.abstract: Almost all of the world’s e-cigarettes are made without oversight, and experts say flawed or sloppy manufacturing could account for some of the hazards seen in the devices.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHENZHEN, China — In a grimy workshop, among boiling vats of chemicals, factory workers are busy turning stainless steel rods into slender tube casings, a crucial component of electronic cigarettes. Not long ago, Skorite Electronics was a tiny firm struggling to produce pen parts. Today, it is part of an enormous — and virtually unregulated — supply chain centered here that produces about 90 percent of the world’s e-cigarettes.

articles.headline: G.O.P. Hopefuls Honing Attacks Against Hillary Clinton
articles.snippet: To win the party’s nomination in a contest over which Mrs. Clinton looms so large, likely Republican candidates are now jockeying to appeal to key groups.
articles.abstract: To win the party’s nomination in a contest over which Mrs. Clinton looms so large, likely Republican candidates are now jockeying to appeal to key groups.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie offered a cutting assessment of Hillary Rodham Clinton’s electoral weaknesses recently, telling a group of energy executives that she lacked her husband’s political talents and personal appeal. To punctuate the point, the New Jersey governor mischievously quoted President Obama from a 2008 campaign debate. “You’re likable enough, Hillary,” Mr. Christie said, according to two participants.

articles.headline: Downbeat Legacy for James Brown, Godfather of Soul: A Will in Dispute
articles.snippet: Nearly eight years after James Brown died, his disputed will remains mired in lawsuits, and a trust set up for needy children has yet to aid its intended recipients.
articles.abstract: Nearly eight years after James Brown died, his disputed will remains mired in lawsuits, and a trust set up for needy children has yet to aid its intended recipients.
articles.lead_paragraph: AIKEN, S.C. — James Brown’s will was meant to be everything his life was not.
articles.byline: By Larry Rohter and Steve Knopper

articles.headline: An Ebola Orphan’s Plea in Africa: ‘Do You Want Me?’
articles.snippet: After her mother died of Ebola, a young girl in Sierra Leone was left an orphan when nobody in her village, even relatives, wanted to take her, though she showed no symptoms of the virus.
articles.abstract: After her mother died of Ebola, a young girl in Sierra Leone was left an orphan when nobody in her village, even relatives, wanted to take her, though she showed no symptoms of the virus.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORT LOKO, Sierra Leone — Sweetie Sweetie had no choice.

articles.headline: Israel’s Gas Offers Lifeline for Peace
articles.snippet: A new bonanza of resources could improve the nation’s ties with Egypt, Jordan and even the Palestinian Authority. The linchpin of this diplomatic push: an oil company in Texas.
articles.abstract: A new bonanza of resources could improve the nation’s ties with Egypt, Jordan and even the Palestinian Authority. The linchpin of this diplomatic push: an oil company in Texas.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE TAMAR PLATFORM, Israel — Alarms rang out across the Tamar natural gas platform off the coast of Israel.
articles.byline: By Stanley Reed and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: Backing C.I.A., Cheney Revisits Torture Debate From Bush Era
articles.snippet: Former Vice President Dick Cheney mounted a spirited rebuttal to the Senate committee’s torture report, saying there was no comparison between the C.I.A.’s tactics and terrorists’ actions.
articles.abstract: Former Vice President Dick Cheney mounted a spirited rebuttal to the Senate committee’s torture report, saying there was no comparison between the C.I.A.’s tactics and terrorists’ actions.
articles.lead_paragraph: As vice president, Dick Cheney was the most enthusiastic sponsor for the brutal C.I.A. interrogation program used on Al Qaeda suspects, protesting when President George W. Bush scaled it back in his second term. Now that a Senate Intelligence Committee report has declared that the C.I.A.’s methods, later prohibited, violated American values and produced little or no useful intelligence, Mr. Cheney is fiercely defending not just the agency’s record, but his own as well.

articles.headline: Sony Pictures Demands That News Agencies Delete ‘Stolen’ Data
articles.snippet: A letter sent to news media outlets warned against using the information revealed by hackers who attacked the studio’s computer systems.
articles.abstract: A letter sent to news media outlets warned against using the information revealed by hackers who attacked the studio’s computer systems.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Sony Pictures Entertainment warned media outlets on Sunday against using the mountains of corporate data revealed by hackers who raided the studio’s computer systems in an attack that became public last month.
articles.byline: By Michael Cieply and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: PetSmart Accepts $8.7 Billion Buyout
articles.snippet: PetSmart announced on Sunday that it would sell itself to an investor group led by the private equity firm BC Partners, in the biggest leveraged buyout of a company this year.
articles.abstract: PetSmart announced on Sunday that it would sell itself to an investor group led by the private equity firm BC Partners, in the biggest leveraged buyout of a company this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: The biggest private equity deal of 2014 — in a year of huge takeovers of cable providers and drug manufacturers — is a bet on the lucrativeness of dog food and catnip.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: In Big Data, Shepherding Comes First
articles.snippet: Aspiring big data software companies find themselves training, advising and building pilot projects for their customers — acting far more as services companies than they hope to be eventually.
articles.abstract: Aspiring big data software companies find themselves training, advising and building pilot projects for their customers — acting far more as services companies than they hope to be eventually.
articles.lead_paragraph: Big data is increasingly moving into the mainstream, as companies in every industry begin to combine an abundance of digital data with smart software to analyze it. It is a potential gold mine for software makers, with analysts predicting torrid growth for the market overall.

articles.headline: Sowing Mayhem, One Click at a Time
articles.snippet: Charles C. Johnson, a blogger based in California, may be the ultimate expression of a certain kind of citizen journalism — one far more toxic than we’re accustomed to seeing.
articles.abstract: Charles C. Johnson, a blogger based in California, may be the ultimate expression of a certain kind of citizen journalism — one far more toxic than we’re accustomed to seeing.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Internet has given us many glorious things: streaming movies, multiplayer games, real-time information and videos of cats playing the piano. It has also offered up some less edifying creations: web-borne viruses, cybercrime and Charles C. Johnson.

articles.headline: Waters Warm, and Cod Catch Ebbs in Maine
articles.snippet: The Gulf of Maine’s waters are warming — faster than almost any ocean waters on earth, scientists say — and fish are voting with their fins for cooler places to live.
articles.abstract: The Gulf of Maine’s waters are warming — faster than almost any ocean waters on earth, scientists say — and fish are voting with their fins for cooler places to live.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Me. — In the vast gulf that arcs from Massachusetts’s shores to Canada’s Bay of Fundy, cod was once king. It paid for fishermen’s boats, fed their families and put their children through college. In one halcyon year in the mid-1980s, the codfish catch reached 25,000 tons.
articles.byline: By Michael Wines and Jess Bidgood

articles.headline: Sony’s International Incident: Making Kim Jong-un’s Head Explode
articles.snippet: Sony’s executives now say they knew that basing a film on the assassination of Kim Jong-un of North Korea had inherent risks.
articles.abstract: Sony’s executives now say they knew that basing a film on the assassination of Kim Jong-un of North Korea had inherent risks.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — When Sony Pictures began casting last year for a new comedy to be called “The Interview,” early scripts included the assassination of a fictionalized North Korean ruler. It was not until auditions began that actors learned that the movie would portray something much more brazen: the violent killing of the actual leader of North Korea, Kim Jong-un.
articles.byline: By Martin Fackler, Brooks Barnes and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: The Rise of a New Smartphone Giant: China’s Xiaomi
articles.snippet: Founded in 2010 to sell cheap phones online, the company has become the No. 3 producer worldwide behind Apple and Samsung and is looking toward Brazil and India.
articles.abstract: Founded in 2010 to sell cheap phones online, the company has become the No. 3 producer worldwide behind Apple and Samsung and is looking toward Brazil and India.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — In China, the smartphone battle used to be Samsung versus Apple. But not anymore.
articles.byline: By Paul Mozur and Shanshan Wang

articles.headline: In Final Spending Bill, Salty Food and Belching Cows Are Winners
articles.snippet: The $1.1 trillion package that cleared the Senate over the weekend was, like many of its predecessors, filled with provisions to satisfy special interests.
articles.abstract: The $1.1 trillion package that cleared the Senate over the weekend was, like many of its predecessors, filled with provisions to satisfy special interests.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Health insurance companies preserved their tax breaks. Farmers and ranchers were spared having to report on pollution from manure. Tourist destinations like Las Vegas benefited from a travel promotion program.

articles.headline: Brennan Draws on Bond With Obama in Backing C.I.A.
articles.snippet: The close relationship that John O. Brennan, the C.I.A. director, has with President Obama helped shape his assertive response to a scathing Senate report on agency torture.
articles.abstract: The close relationship that John O. Brennan, the C.I.A. director, has with President Obama helped shape his assertive response to a scathing Senate report on agency torture.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just hours before he publicly responded last week to the Senate Intelligence Committee report accusing the Central Intelligence Agency of torture and deceit, John O. Brennan, the C.I.A.’s director, stopped by the White House to meet with President Obama.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Mark Mazzetti
